options.D: To avoid competition with Lancia, which used KKK turbochargers in its own racing cars

concepts_tested: Turbocharging technology adaptation from racing to road cars
Engineering trade-offs in vehicle design (e.g., displacement vs. forced induction, mechanical layout changes for performance)
Cause-and-effect relationships in automotive development (e.g., market pressures leading to technical innovations)

questions.question: Why does the chitarra tool's design with parallel wires contribute to the sauce adhesion of spaghetti alla chitarra?

options.A: The wires create a textured surface that increases the pasta's surface area, allowing sauce to cling more effectively.
options.B: The wires cut the dough into uniform strips that are less likely to clump together during cooking.
options.C: The wires compress the dough, forcing air out and creating a denser pasta structure that holds sauce better.
options.D: The wires stretch the dough, increasing its elasticity so it can absorb more sauce during cooking.

The connection between regional variations in pasta names and cultural/technological adaptations of the chitarra method
The role of dough composition (durum wheat, eggs) in determining pasta's cooking properties and traditional uses

questions.question: Why does the chitarra tool's design with parallel wires result in a pasta shape that enhances sauce adhesion compared to round spaghetti?

How the production method of chitarra pasta influences its traditional uses and regional variations

questions.question: Why does the keyhole-shaped perforation in Mellita species represent a secondary adaptation rather than an ancestral trait?

options.D: Because it reduces energy expenditure during burrowing movements

Radial symmetry in echinoids vs. evolved bilateral features
Keyhole-shaped perforation as a secondary adaptation

questions.question: Why does the keyhole-shaped perforation in keyhole sand dollars represent an evolutionary adaptation rather than a primitive trait?

Keyhole-shaped perforation as a secondary feature in an otherwise radially symmetric organism

questions.question: Why might a sprint medley relay team choose to run shorter sprints first, even if it requires athletes to move into a common passing zone?

options.A: Shorter sprints allow for more precise pacing and handoffs, reducing the risk of collisions in shared zones.
options.B: Shorter sprints require less physical conditioning, making them easier to execute in succession.
options.C: The track's design inherently favors shorter distances for the first legs to prevent athletes from losing their lanes.
options.D: Running shorter sprints initially ensures that the team's slower athletes can complete their legs without falling behind.

concepts_tested: The strategic order of shorter sprints first in the SMR for safety and handoff consistency
The relationship between track markings and passing zones to prevent chaos during exchanges
The mathematical rationale for using even-numbered laps in SMR configurations

questions.question: Why does the movable do solfège system, as used in tonic sol-fa, provide an advantage for teaching sight-singing compared to fixed do systems?

options.A: It allows students to recognize intervals more easily by anchoring each note to a fixed pitch reference.
options.B: It enables students to understand tonal relationships within different keys by keeping do as the tonic of the key.
options.C: It simplifies the learning of complex rhythms by aligning solfège syllables with standard time signatures.
options.D: It enhances pitch accuracy by assigning unique solfège syllables to each note of the chromatic scale.

concepts_tested: Movable Do Solfège System
Tonal Relationships in Musical Notation
Educational Pedagogy for Sight-Singing

questions.question: Why does the movable do solfège system used in tonic sol-fa enhance sight-singing learning compared to fixed do systems?

options.A: Because it allows singers to recognize intervals relative to the key center rather than absolute pitches.
options.B: Because it simplifies vocal ranges by eliminating sharps and flats from notation.
options.C: Because it aligns with the natural overtone series in human vocal production.
options.D: Because it enables musicians to transpose music more easily between different clefs.

concepts_tested: Movable Do Solfège System
Tonal Relationships in Music Notation
Educational Pedagogy and Methodology

questions.question: Why does the movable do system in Tonic Sol-Fa require that 'do' always corresponds to the tonic of the key being used, rather than a fixed pitch?

options.A: To allow for easier transition between different keys without needing new notation symbols.
options.B: To preserve historical syllables from Guido de Arezzo's original system that started with 'Ut'.
options.C: To ensure that the sequence of solfège syllables remains consistent across all musical modes.
options.D: To align with the fixed do system's notation used by Jean-Jacques Rousseau in France.

concepts_tested: Movable Do System in Tonic Sol-Fa
Relationship Between Solfège Syllables and Key Relationships
Adaptation of Earlier Systems into Tonic Sol-Fa

questions.question: Why does the movable do solfège system in tonic sol-fa require that 'do' be relative to the key rather than fixed to a specific pitch?

options.A: To allow for easier transposition between keys without changing the syllable assignments
options.B: To preserve historical continuity with Guido de Arezzo's original solfège system
options.C: To ensure that hand signals can be universally applied across all keys and octaves
options.D: To simplify the learning process by reducing the number of unique syllables needed for different keys

concepts_tested: Movable Do Solfège System
Relationship Between Tonic and Key Signature
Adaptation and Evolution of Musical Notation Systems

questions.question: Genetic studies of ancient Armenians from the Armenian Highlands show minimal female gene pool changes over millennia. Which principle best explains this stability in genetic markers despite cultural transitions?

options.A: Founder effect limiting genetic diversity
options.B: Cultural diffusion as the primary vector for population change
options.C: High rates of male-dominated migration and admixture
options.D: Genetic drift due to small population sizes

concepts_tested: Genetic continuity of Armenians in the Armenian Highlands
Cultural diffusion model as an explanation for lack of female gene pool changes
Relationship between genetic admixture periods and historical cultural transitions

questions.question: The genetic continuity observed in Armenian populations, with minimal admixture since the 12th century BC, is most strongly supported by which of the following principles or mechanisms?

options.A: The Last Glacial Maximum caused a population bottleneck that restricted gene flow into the Armenian Highlands.
options.B: Cultural diffusion facilitated the spread of technologies and languages without significant genetic mixing.
options.C: The geographic isolation of the Armenian Highlands prevented external migration and admixture.
options.D: Neolithic farmer expansion into Europe resulted in genetic homogenization of the Near East.

concepts_tested: Genetic continuity and admixture in Armenian populations over time
Cultural diffusion as a mechanism for societal development in the Armenian Highlands
The role of the Last Glacial Maximum in population dynamics and settlement patterns

questions.question: Why does a blast gate's default closed position enhance material extraction efficiency when opened?

options.A: It reduces the risk of system overpressure by limiting airflow when not in use.
options.B: It allows the system to build up pressure differential when opened, maximizing suction at that location.
options.C: It prevents dust from settling in the ductwork when the system is idle.
options.D: It ensures even distribution of suction across all connected machinery.

concepts_tested: Blast gates use a default closed position to block airflow, allowing focused suction when opened. This mechanism ensures maximum material extraction at a specific location.
Multiple blast gates can be opened simultaneously in powerful systems without reducing individual suction efficiency, indicating a scalable design principle.
The necessity of keeping at least one blast gate open in some systems to prevent system collapse highlights a relationship between airflow dynamics and system stability.
